item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: 100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet Stands His Ground; Voices of Residents Must be Heard

Today, Wednesday August 26th, the city came back again at 5am to sweep away about 100 people from where many of them had been staying for months. Residents of this area were specifically told by police they did not know where they could move to. At least off camera they admitted the truth!@# Many people were in tears and turmoil trying to figure out where to mo...ve after the sweep. A couple people were given one or two night hotel vouchers...and than they will be back on the streets dealing with the same search for where to stay as they await housing to be made attainable.
3.jpg

Four protesters were arrested after being in the street briefly trying to film the situation. Police bumrushed them, brutally hurting at least two of them, and arresting 4 people simply for being in the street for a short time, most not even blocking traffic. A few minutes later, people were standing in the street doing the exact same thing right in front of police and none of them were arrested. Yet another example why money to fund police should be used on housing and resources, not police.

Hear the voices from the street.
Words from the Street...Before August 26th Sweep

"'It’s very stressful, this constant moving. "
"They are complicating our survival."
"We have a right to be here, we have a right not to go to the shelter with bed bugs."
"Fuck the Puereos"
"It makes me feel good that people care and are helping."
"I have no where to go."
"We are not cattle."
"Until they offer me a home, I will be in this spot with my tent."
"This is where my case manager can find me, my path to housing."
"Give me one logical reason why I have to move."
"The only way I will move my stuff is if they hand me a lease to an apartment. "

Contact:
info@denverhomelessoutloud.org
720-940-5291

See More
item.author: Denver Homeless Out Loud

item.title: 100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

100 People without Housing Swept to Nowhere Today: Disabled Vet Stands His Ground; Voices of Residents Must be Heard

Today, Wednesday August 26th, the city came back again at 5am to sweep away about 100 people from where many of them had been staying for months. Residents of this area were specifically told by police they did not know where they could move to. At least off camera they admitted the truth!@# Many people were in tears and turmoil trying to figure out where to mo...ve after the sweep. A couple people were given one or two night hotel vouchers...and than they will be back on the streets dealing with the same search for where to stay as they await housing to be made attainable.

Four protesters were arrested after being in the street briefly trying to film the situation. Police bumrushed them, brutally hurting at least two of them, and arresting 4 people simply for being in the street for a short time, most not even blocking traffic. A few minutes later, people were standing in the street doing the exact same thing right in front of police and none of them were arrested. Yet another example why money to fund police should be used on housing and resources, not police.

Hear the voices from the street.

Words from the Street...Before August 26th Sweep

It’s very stressful, this constant moving.

They are complicating our survival.

We have a right to be here, we have a right not to go to the shelter with bed bugs.

Fuck the Puereos

It makes me feel good that people care and are helping.

I have no where to go.

We are not cattle.

Until they offer me a home, I will be in this spot with my tent.

This is where my case manager can find me, my path to housing.

Give me one logical reason why I have to move.

The only way I will move my stuff is if they hand me a lease to an apartment.

item.title: Cathay Alderman, of Denver’s Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, agreed. “If you’re going to tell us that there is a Hepatitis outbreak then go in and treat it like a Hepatitis outbreak,” Alderman said. “Don’t treat it like a camping ban enforcement.” , denverpost.com/2020/08/26/den…

item.title: Cathay Alderman, of Denver’s Colorado Coalition for the...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

Cathay Alderman, of Denver’s Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, agreed. “If you’re going to tell us that there is a Hepatitis outbreak then go in and treat it like a Hepatitis outbreak,” Alderman said. “Don’t treat it like a camping ban enforcement.”
----
Well said, by Cathy Alderman. The city will use any excuse to break up encampments
--------
If you don have a sub to the post txt of article below

...Continue ReadingDenver officials cited outbreaks of Hepatitis and Shigella when they resumed homeless sweeps last month, but a national expert and a local advocate say the numbers of positive tests don’t jus…

denverpost.com

Outbreaks don’t justify breaking up Denver’s homeless camps, expert says

Denver officials cited outbreaks of Hepatitis and Shigella when they resumed homeless sweeps last month, but a national expert and a local advocate say the numbers of positive tests don’t jus…Denver officials cited outbreaks of Hepatitis and Shigella when they resumed homeless sweeps last month, but a national expert and a local advocate say the numbers of positive tests don’t jus…

item.title: @20 sec "Enforcing Denvers camping ban can be...
item.content:encoded:
Denver Homeless Out Loud

@20 sec "Enforcing Denvers camping ban can be complicated and dificult"
---
The camping ban is also unconstitutional.... they forgot to report that. See what else you can note they forgot to report on...
Like forgetting to talk to a spokesperson from the protesters...
Did you know the reporter was standing on block from the Colorado Coalition for the Homeless, half a block from Metro Denver Homeless Initiative, and half a block from DHOL? He could see the signs on the buil...dings from where he was standing. Couldn't bother to walk across the parking lot get some expert comments from expert organizations that have been next to this camp for years... likely to comment very differently than the police PR person. Shoddy one sided reporting.
Oh he did not mention the evictions that are curently occuring did he? Do you think that was on purpose?

Expect...
1-Not enough sanctioned camps (Current total =0)
2-City to criminalize folks unable to squeeze in
3-People to be on streets all over the city
4-100K people still awaiting eviction

https://denver.cbslocal.com/…/veteran-cop-must-maintain-ba…/

See MoreOne of Denver's most respected and tenured police officers said she understands why many may not agree with the sweeps of homeless camps.

denver.cbslocal.com

Veteran Cop Must Maintain 'Balancing Act' As Police Engage With Homeless During Sweeps

One of Denver's most respected and tenured police officers said she understands why many may not agree with the sweeps of homeless camps.One of Denver's most respected and tenured police officers said she understands why many may not agree with the sweeps of homeless camps.

item.title: "Others, she says, have tried to access services only to be let down" - The “let down” is common. "Services" are not available to most, it is so competitive for these services and there is so much red tape/restrictions to access its ridiculous. denver.cbslocal.com/2020/08/05/den…

item.title:
Friends! We're new here but decided to kick it off with a thread on concerning trends we're seeing in Denver for those experiencing, or at-risk of, #homelessness.
@COCoalition @homelessoutloud @deloresproject @StFrancisCenter @denverrescue

item.title:
38% of people in city court don't have homes.
30% of people in city court are Black in a city that is 10% Black.
70% of scofflaw cases among the unhoused get dismissed.
So why are people getting arrested in the first place?
dnvr.it/33ztDR9
item.content:encoded: 38% of people in city court don't have homes. 30% of people in city court are Black in a city that is 10% Black. 70% of scofflaw cases among the unhoused get dismissed. So why are people getting arrested in the first place? dnvr.it/33ztDR9
